body.p: Graduated from Harvard in 1854, then joined the U.S. Military Academy at West Point. Graduated from the West Point on July 1, 1858, and joined the Corps of Engineers. After graduation served at West Point as an assistant instructor of practical engineering, and as an assistant engineer in construction attached to the Company of Engineers stationed at West Point. From 1860 to 1861, he served as a Second Lieutenant in the Corps of Engineers at the Fort at Clark’s Point (Since renamed Fort Rodham) in Bristol County, Massachusetts. On August 6, 1861, William C. Paine became a First Lieutenant in the Corps of Engineers, and helped repair Fort Schuyler, in New York Harbor. With the outbreak of the Civil War he served in many engineer related posts, including in the defense of Washington D.C, the construction of the defenses of Portland, Maine, and the defenses of Portsmouth New Hampshire. He was promoted to Captain on March 3, 1863. His brother, Sumner, a second lieutenant in the “Harvard Regiment” 20th Massachusetts Infantry, was killed in the battle of Gettysburg on July 3, 1863. William himself became injured sometime around July 6, 1863, and resigned from the army on November 6, 1863, to return to his family farm in Massachusetts, where he served out the rest of the war.
